column4: if i install xfce or something to that effect (to appease newb sysadmin =P), can i do so without installing gdm/kdm so it doesnt run all the time?
i just want to use startx when its needed
docteh: i guess that would work.
you can just apt-get install xfce4
you will then only get the DE
removing ubuntu-desktop does nothing, its a hollow meta-package
it will be needed to change release though
sure it does, it uninstalls the package
use:   sudo -i   instead
That worked, thanks.  Why does this happen?
one is righ, sudo su is wrong
sudo -i   gives an (i)nteractive sudo
if you run more cpu intensive tasks, does it increase?
try: sudo cpufreq-selector -c 0 -f 800000
also try:  echo "1200000" | sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_setspeed; echo "800000" | sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu1/cpufreq/scaling_setspeed
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/519142 is the source
Thanks, but no joy.  I don't even have a cpufreq subdirectory under /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0
try:  modprobe -vv acpi_cpufreq
even with -vv, modprobe shows no output, and again nothing is written to dmesg.. that seems really strange to me.  Isn't there generally _something_ written to dmesg when a module is loaded?
usually
sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get upgrade
or you may find a PPA
